ul: For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
li: Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.

Set the Secure flag on cookies. Set the requireSSL property to true for the httpCookies element in the web.config file, like this: <httpcookies requiressl="true"></httpcookies> If you use Forms Authentication, you will also need to set requireSSL to true for the forms element.
For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
p: Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS and set the Secure flag on session cookies.

If session identifiers are transmitted in plain-text, an attacker can intercept them using a man-in-the-middle attack. After intercepting a session identifier, the attacker can hijack the corresponding session. Hijacking a session allows the attacker to carry out any action that is available to the authenticated user. To prevent session identifiers from being sent in plain-text, session cookies should be sent only using SSL/TLS.
To send session cookies only using SSL/TLS:
ol:
Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.
 Set the Secure flag on cookies. Set the requireSSL property to true for the httpCookies element in the web.config file, like this: <httpcookies requiressl="true"></httpcookies> If you use Forms Authentication, you will also need to set requireSSL to true for the forms element.
strong: Set the Secure flag on cookies.

html:
Applies To

  • ASP.NET

What to Do

Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS and set the Secure flag on session cookies.

Why

If session identifiers are transmitted in plain-text, an attacker can intercept them using a man-in-the-middle attack. After intercepting a session identifier, the attacker can hijack the corresponding session. Hijacking a session allows the attacker to carry out any action that is available to the authenticated user. To prevent session identifiers from being sent in plain-text, session cookies should be sent only using SSL/TLS.

How

To send session cookies only using SSL/TLS:

  1. Configure IIS to use SSL/TLS. Get a valid certificate. Hosting service providers often sell valid SSL certificates. Install the certificate. Create an HTTPS binding for the site. A link in the "Additional Resources" section describes how to do this in detail.
  2. Set the Secure flag on cookies. Set the requireSSL property to true for the httpCookies element in the web.config file, like this: <httpcookies requiressl="true"></httpcookies> If you use Forms Authentication, you will also need to set requireSSL to true for the forms element.

Additional Resources

  • For information about setting up SSL on IIS, see http://www.iis.net/learn/manage/configuring-security/how-to-set-up-ssl-on-iis
